resources.string: Il-Hyung Cho is an associate professor and chair of the Department of Computer Science at Saginaw Valley State University, Michigan, where he has been since 2003. During 2010-2011 he was a Visiting Professor of Bioinformatics lab at Washington State University. He received a B.E. in Electronic & Computer Engineering from Yonsei University in 1987, and an M.S. in Computer Science from Bowling Green State University. He received his Ph.D. in Computer Science from Clemson University in 2000. He worked at Iona Technologies in Boston as a software engineer in 2000-2001, and at Clemson University as visiting lecturer in 2001-2003. \n\nHis research interests center on object oriented system design, distributed object systems, software engineering, bioinfomatics tools development, and computer security and forensics. He helped the construction of genome database for Rosaceae Crop (www.rosaceae.org/). He has given many talks in professional conferences and SE&T colloquium, most recently at Oxford University (UK) on the topic of Business Innovation with User Knowledge and IT Technologies.

George Corser is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science and Information Systems (CSIS) at Saginaw Valley State University (SVSU). His research defines and analyzes location privacy and security protocols in vehicle networks. His teaching explores web and mobile app development, theoretical computer science and cybercrime. His professional service includes advisory and leadership positions in SVSU student organizations, international technical societies, and a cybercrime analysis consortium.

I graduated with PhD in Computational Analysis and Modeling (2013) from Louisiana Tech University, Ruston, USA. Prior that, I received MS and BSc in Computer Science and Engineering from University of Dhaka, Bangladesh in 2008 and 2006 respectively. I received MS in Mathematics (2011) and MS in Computer Science (2013) from Louisiana Tech University. Before joining SVSU in 2013, I was a research assistant from March, 2009 to February, 2013 at Center for Secure Cyberspace at Louisiana Tech University.\n\n My research interests include detecting and mitigating cyber-behavioral anomalies, behavioral biometrics, machine learning, knowledge discovery from data, image processing and human activity detection from video. I am a member of IEEE and ACM.
